name: Roseate Spoonbill
description: As the only spoonbill with a bare head in adulthood, it is not white but predominantly pink. Young birds acquire this adult appearance gradually, initially showing only a slight pinkish tint and a fully feathered head.
spread_note: From southern Georgia and Florida through Central America to Argentina
food_note: Small fish, crustaceans, aquatic insects, and mollusks
image_alt: Roseate Spoonbill, photo: Petr Rošický, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 59–77 cm; tail length 10–11 cm; weight 1.1–1.4 kg
attractions: In the 19th century, it was abundant along the Gulf of Mexico. Between 1880 and 1940, it was nearly wiped out due to the feather trade. Subsequent protection efforts have raised its population to around 3,500 pairs today.
breeding: Roseate spoonbills are a traditional species here—the first were kept in 1950. From 1973 to 1997, they were absent from Prague Zoo. Then a pair from Augsburg arrived, founding a successful breeding program that continues today.
